channel.title: Sorry, not really sorry btw
channel.description:
just wanted to send a message to all you fellow moparians, it goes like this:
i'm sorry(ha) everyone who i've been a dick to on the forum, or sarcastically unpleasant. i didn't create this topic to get some sort of support, friends or anything like that. this is also [b]not[/b] a leaving thread. i'm just enjoying life a lot more since i've left the rsps scene (although you may see me replying to help threads occasional), and i think it would benefit you also if you did the same thing, so yeah.
people release what you gotta release on the thread and it's done.
u mirin brah?

item.title: Sorry, not really sorry btw
item.dc:creator: @Acorn1 Acorn_
item.description:
@Acorn1 wrote:

OP is clearly homosexual and alone if he allows RSPS to come between him and his happiness.

Read full topic

item.title: Sorry, not really sorry btw
item.dc:creator: @Vexx Vexx
item.description:
@Vexx wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:13, topic:480846”][quote author=vexx1345 link=topic=599084.msg4211349#msg4211349 date=1359584467]

u mirin?

What the [shadow=black,left]f[/shadow]uck does that even mean?
[/quote]Mirin is a Japanese condiment which contains about 14% alcohol. To make mirin, steamed mochi-gome (glutinous rice), kome-koji (cultured rice), and shochu (distilled alcoholic beverage) are mixed and fermented for about 2 months. Mirin produced this way is called hon-mirin, as distinguished from mirin-style condiments (mirin-fu chomiryo) which is made to resemble the flavor of mirin. Mirin-style condiments contain less than 1% alcohol, and they are usually cheaper than hon-mirin. Well-known Japanese brands for mirin are Takara and Mitsukan.[/quote]
So he is calling me a condiment… I am offended by these accusations.

Read full topic

[quote=“vexx1345, post:12, topic:480846”][quote author=Int Bauk link=topic=599084.msg4211328#msg4211328 date=1359583174]
u mirin?
[/quote]
What the [shadow=black,left]f[/shadow]uck does that even mean?[/quote]Mirin is a Japanese condiment which contains about 14% alcohol. To make mirin, steamed mochi-gome (glutinous rice), kome-koji (cultured rice), and shochu (distilled alcoholic beverage) are mixed and fermented for about 2 months. Mirin produced this way is called hon-mirin, as distinguished from mirin-style condiments (mirin-fu chomiryo) which is made to resemble the flavor of mirin. Mirin-style condiments contain less than 1% alcohol, and they are usually cheaper than hon-mirin. Well-known Japanese brands for mirin are Takara and Mitsukan.
